review: The author's writing echoes the styles of renowned short story writers such as Lorrie Moore, George Saunders, Paul Tremblay, Stephen King, Alice Munro, and Kurt Vonnegut. She masterfully navigates the space between genre and literary fiction, crafting captivating and authentic worlds within this delicate balance.

A skilled storyteller has the power to craft immersive worlds that suspend our disbelief, whether through novels or short stories. Unfortunately, short story writers often don't receive the recognition they deserve for their ability to develop entire universes within a limited space—sometimes encapsulated in just one sentence or paragraph. World-building isn't exclusive to genre fiction; it can unfold in any setting, time period, or even within a character's mind.

This collection intricately weaves interconnected stories that mirror our own reality. It delves into themes such as Millennials navigating a flawed world passed down from previous generations, as well as challenges posed by social media, global warming, gentrification, and wealth inequality. Blending science fiction, horror, romance, and humor, the stories create a seamless fusion of genres.
conclusion: *Island Rule* is a masterful collection of subtly interconnected short stories that blend genres and explore deeply relevant themes. The author's ability to build immersive worlds in limited space is remarkable, and the writing draws comparisons to some of the greatest short story authors. The collection is both imaginative and grounded, offering a poignant reflection of our own world.

review: This book masterfully weaves connections between its stories, presenting a glimpse into a near-future United States. I both appreciate and resent the open-ended conclusion; while some narratives extend into others, it’s clear that the storylines are far from finished.

Agatha is a polisher on the least successful team, dedicated to helping individuals fit into societal norms. While she enjoys her work, it leaves her feeling unfulfilled. Geils, on the other hand, struggled to find his place in society. In his moody teenage years, he found solace in nature, experiencing some of his happiest moments on campus. After failing as an urban planner, he became a polisher alongside Agatha, which only deepened his depression. Agatha is repulsed by the lingering scent of nature that Geils carries, while Geils finds sadness in the societal expectations Agatha represents. Ultimately, they must part ways, yet each retains a piece of Goldenrod's teeth—a symbol of their connection that hints at the possibility of reunion in the future.
The ending featuring Agatha and Geils beautifully encapsulates the tension between society and nature.
This book is truly wonderful—perhaps one of the best I've read in years.
conclusion: This book is a deeply engaging and thought-provoking read, blending interconnected stories with rich symbolism and character dynamics. While the lack of a definitive conclusion may frustrate some, it adds to the book's unique charm and leaves room for interpretation and future possibilities.
